text: 750 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 2/25/2014. Pours hazy very dark reddish brown color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of huge raisin, prune, cherry, plum, fig, date, apricot, apple, red grape, sherry, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, bourbon, maple syrup, vanilla, peppercorn, toasted oak, and brown bread; with lighter notes of coconut, chocolate, cocoa, leather, tobacco, herbal, and yeast/oak/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel notes; with great strength. Boozy aromas as it warms, but not overwhelming. Taste of huge raisin, prune, cherry, plum, fig, date, apricot, apple, red grape, sherry, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, bourbon, maple syrup, vanilla, peppercorn, toasted oak, and brown bread; with lighter notes of coconut, chocolate, cocoa, leather, tobacco, herbal, and yeast/oak/toasted earthiness. Light herbal/woody bitterness and bourbon/tannic oak spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark fruit, cherry, apricot, apple, red grape, sherry, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, bourbon, maple syrup, vanilla, peppercorn, toasted oak, brown bread, coconut, light chocolate/cocoa, herbal, and yeast/oak/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel flavors; with a fantastic malt and bourbon/oak spiciness balance, with zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light dryness from bourbon/oak spiciness, lightly increasing through the glass. Light-medium carbonation and full body; with a smooth, creamy/slick, and lightly syrupy/tannic/sticky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden; a small pleasant warmth with a bit of booziness lingering after the finish, but not overwhelming. Overall this is an incredible barrel aged old ale. All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel flavors; very smooth and dangerously easy to sip on for the enormous ABV. A bit more boozy and sweet than previous releases due the higher ABV; but also less earthy/leathery and lacking the butterscotch notes of the past 2 100% BBA versions. More tannic/drying from the barrels. A highly enjoyable offering regardless.
A bottle on Black Christmas 2016 at 12 Kings. Vintage 2014. Pours a hazy dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, molasses. Taste is sweet, dark fruits, molasses. Very pleasant.

August 13, 2016. Bottle at Bruery Bonanza 2016, as Bois (Rye Whiskey Barrel). Thanks for sharing! 
Brown with a minimal tan head. Aroma is sweet, malty, slight boozy with caramel, vanilla, prunes, figs, wood, hints of spicy rye and a metallic notes. Taste is sweet, malty and slightly boozy. Finish is warming alcohol with a spicy rye whiskey note, 
sweet dark sugars, caramel, vanilla, dried fruits and a light metallic note. Full bodied, soft carbonation, slight sticky texture. 
Good and heavy but the light metallic note bring it down.
A: Deep dark brown with a thin light brown head. N: Figs, vanilla, barrels T: Vanilla, figs, apricot O: Decent with a lot of barrels to it.

From notes. Enjoyed this one at the Brew Crew Bash in Ann Arbor on May 21. This one was poured from a 750 mL bottle. The pour is a dark, dark copper color, hints of mahogany throughout with a nice dark khaki colored head that falls to a wispy film. There is no lace left to this one. The aroma is, well a booze bomb right up front, but hey, its The Bruery, so of course it is. The molasses and brown sugars really come through with a nice maltiness. The whiskey is nice. There is a lot of vanilla in this as it warms. There is a nice woodiness and a light caramel as it moves through. The flavors match this one nicely. There is a good bourbon heat up front, and a lightly spicy rye to go with the sweet vanilla and caramel. The dark fruits move in and offer a great lead for the burnt sugars and molasses sweetness. The mouth feel is thick and viscous, with a nice soft carbonation that helps it coat the mouth beautifully. The aftertaste is complex and delicious. There is a lot of caramel, vanilla, molasses and a strong whiskey presence. Its truly a beautiful beer.

750 ml bottle shared with Tmoney99 and the Fifty West guys. Pours a dark auburn brown color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have sweet malts, caramel, brown sugar, toffee, vanilla, rye whiskey character, wood, definitely a sipper and happy to have shared with the group.

Silver waxed 750ml Sucre bottle (that only took a light degree of a Herculean effort to remove the cap from under the wax) pours with a dirty murky brackish brown mud that supports a nice dark tan head that has some swirls of lighter tan to white foam. THIS is a fine looking beer. The aroma offers up sweet supple malts and molasses and other residual sugar pillowiness as well as lighter notes of stunted and muted wood, marshmallow and a sense of boozy spirits with a wink toward whiskey. The taste almost cavitates across the palate with smooth soft sloughing malts and molasses followed by residual sugar coated wood and blunted chopped off at the knees- spicy whiskey notes. After several sips it becomes apparent that theres a mild warming sensation from the esophagus and heading south into the belly. As it warms a bit of plum and fig sweet dark fruity esters are noticed well off in the background. Terrific treat of a sipper.

At Bruery Sucré Tasting in the Bierboom. Head and colour are the same as that of the Rum version. Aroma very similar to the Rum version as well, with the same solvent-like alcohol presence, but more vanilla and cherry sweetness too, making it more pleasant. Tastes sweeter too, somewhere in between the Rum and the Port version. Among the best ones in this series, to my taste.
Bottle. Pours clear dark copper. Aroma huge vanilla, caramel, oak, bourbon, and huge molasses notes. Flavor matches the aroma but comes off a little thin. Medium body.
(En fût à la brasserie): La signature Bois avec ses sucres enracinés et lexubérance du Rye Whiskey. Très solide variante.

Large shared bottle.
Sweet appealing aroma with hints of whisky, wood, toffee and Dark dried fruits.
Flavor is overly boozy, unless you are hoping for lots of whisky. Nonetheless, quite pleasing, nicely complex, and only lightly hot.
Moderately sweet.
Bottle tasted in May 2015. Aroma oak, whiskey, dark fruit. Taste prune, whiskey, caramel, molasses. Pretty good. Hard hitter (duh).
750 rye sucre, light grey wax. Booze forward like you would expect from a 16% bruery beer. Caramel and toffee. Thick body for a barleywine/old ale.

Bottle shared at a BOSS meeting at Snyders place. Pours brown with a very thin head. Aroma is toffee, chocolate, sweet dark fruits. Really nice. Flavor follows and is very sweet. Sticky sweet. Very nice in sips, but not much more. Great beer.
Shared bottle. Pours a hazy reddish brown with a decent beige head. Aroma of whiskey, fruit, and caramel. Taste is whiskey, dark fruit, caramel, vanilla, spice, and wood. Nice sipper.

750ml bottle pours a reddy brown color without much head. Sharp alcohol that quickly blows off. Tasted alongside the bourbon and Madeira barrel aged. Mild burnt toffee that is a little more prominent than the base sucre.
750ml bottle. Bois version (2013). Poured a hazy amber color with an off white head. Woody/oak, vanilla, dark fruits, caramel, bourbon, and brown sugar.
750 shared by Kyler. Bruery Rye Whisky on label. Big sweet boozy whiskey on the nose little spicy. These beers are too sweet for me.

Poured from a Rye Whiskey Bois bottle. 
Aroma is fairly malty with lits of caramel and toffee with a lighter toasted bread note. Medium dried fruit notes of raisin, fig and prunes. Some alcohol spice with medium light rye whiskey and light oak character. Hints of vanilla, chocolate and roast. 
Pours a murky reddish brown with a moderate sized, moderately thick, tan head that recedes somewhat quickly to the edges where it lingers in clumps. 
Flavor is fairly sweet with a ton of caramel, toffee and burnt sugar. Moderate toast and faint roast and chocolate balance out the sugar a little bit. Medium light notes of raisins, figs and prunes. Light oak and medium bitterness. Medium light rye whiskey note. Faint vanilla and leather. Some alcohol spice. 
Mouthfeel is full bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a nice big beer but not remarkably different from the regular bourbon barrel aged version. Very sweet and boozy, but with good malt complexity and barrel notes. A nicely done large beer.

Bottle... Pours murky and light brown with a petite, fleeting, mushroom-colored head. The aroma is constructed of caramel, wood and whiskey with some dustiness. Full-bodied and chewy with buzzing carbonation. The sweet flavor presents singed caramel, whiskey, a woodsy note and earthy bitterness. Lengthy, hearty, warming finale. Bottle courtesy of biggsbowler!

Bottle at James for the multi-K tasting. Pours a clear brown with a thin white head. Rye whiskey, warm sweet caramel and wood. Medium bodied, big and warm, lots of whiskey coming through, spicy and hot. Warming alcohol into the finish, lingering wood.

Alcohol is apparent straight away. Aroma is sweet caramel and toffee with whiskey notes and light fruit. Body is full. Again, toffee and light fruit lead, but alcohol dryness quickly sweeps up the palate. A good beer, but not the best in the series.

Bottle at 12K joint tasting brought by Matt, labelled as Bois in Whiskey barrels. Dark brown with no head to speak off. Sweet raisin, plum, whiskey, vanilla, surprisingly strong carbonation and full body, some syrup, anise and maple syrup, darkly roasted malts, boozy.

750 ML bottle Bois label 

Dark amber color, thin ring of light brown lacing. Big ABV legs with this. 
Big brown sugar, caramel, whiskey, vanilla, and coconut. Subtle spice and oak. Booze not as bad as the other variants. 
Taste is sweet, slick and slightly spicy. Lots of vanilla and coconut. Full bodied is a safe thing to say. Sipper and better shared really. Best of last years versions by far.
750ml bottle. As bois. This was the sweetest of the gang, just booze and malt, some balsamic without the sourness. diabetes.
Bottle 2013 Bois version. deep red/copper color with solid khaki head. Aroma of spice, bread, caramel. Taste is sweet and boozy with loads of caramel and vanilla.

sample at Crabbapple bottle tasting. caramel colored pour, fuller body, caramel toffee forward, dark fruits, raisins, vanilla & pretty big whiskey notes. Toffee & whicsky barrell worked well together. definite sipper, aggressive, very big beer at 16%

Bottle: Poured a deep cloudy brown color ale with a medium off-white head. Aroma of loads of caramelized malt with some brown sugar notes and some dry fruits with light liquor notes also noticeable. Taste is mix between some caramelized sugar notes with some brown sugar, vanilla and dry raisins notes. Whiskey and vanilla notes are also easily identifiable. Body is quite full with medium carbonation and light warming alcohol notes are noticeable. Big beer for sure with probably too much residual sugars but somehow I found it very enjoyable in small serving.

Bottle at Jester King. Brown pour with a tan head. The aroma is fairly strong with some boozy character as well as some brown sugar and oak. The flavor is a meld of many different notes. I get a lot of barrel aged character including some vanilla and oak. There is also some spicy rye whiskey, molasses and a hint of dark fruit. Fairly boozy overall. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Nice beer.

Bottle received in trade from TexIndy, thanks for the opportunity!
Shared with a few folks sitting around a campfire at Robs
Huge oak and brown sugar with lots of fruit and a touch of warming alcohol. Not much of the spirit left, but a great beer to sip with friends.

Label said "Bois". Pours brown limited head lots of lacing. Nose is big huge vanilla and lots of whiskey. Flavours of vanilla, mollasses, pepper. Fully creamy body with lively carbonation. Heavy sweet wth medium bitterness. A big bomb of a beer, but a beauty!

A hazed dark brown ale with a thin mocha head. In aroma, nice sweet fruity chocolate malt with light bourbon barrel, licorice, alcohol warmth, dark fruits, plums, very nice. In mouth, a beautiful complex mix of dark fruits, Dutch apple jam, sirop de Liège, maple, licorice, alcohol warmth, beautiful. Thanks Matt.

Draft at Gingerman during the Bruery tap takeover event with Chris and Streets. Pours a deep brownish body with thin off white lacing. Aroma is faint sweet character, like oak, sugary booze - sort of blending into the rest of the high-octane Bruery ales that night. Mouthfeel is on the lighter side with notes of sweet booze, oak, vanilla, sugary malt, dark fruit and maple. Not my favorite of the night.

Bottle. No label taken. Pours dark caramel. Pours rye, oak, caramel, dark fruit, whiskey and toffee. Medium body. Earlier Rating: 4/6/2014 Total Score: 4Bottle (Bois) at 7K/5K. Pours caramel brown with off white head. Nose/taste of rye, oak, caramel, whiskey, vanilla and earthy caramel. Full bodied. Thick.
Bottle. Brown pour with some head. Rye, light oak, sweet and malty aromas. Flavors are dark, oak, rye and malt tones.

shared bottle as bruery bois 100% rye whisky barrel aged. poured a murky chesnut brown colour with some white bubbles on top. big alcohol lacing on the side of the glass. big aroma of vanilla, walnuts, toffee, caramel, rye, whisky, oak, malt, strong alcohol notice, long lasting finish. a nice sipper. cant wait to try the other versions!
Hazy toffee color. Small tan head. Little lacing. Big booze aroma and taste. Boozy but tasty.

Bottle thanks to Will. Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is strong rye, wood, booze, figs. Thin mouthfeel with strong rye, booze, wood, figs, sweet finish. Very good.

Tap at The Bruery. Pours brown with a slight head. Aroma of rye spice, alcohol and brown sugar. Full bodied. Flavor is rye (tho not very spicy)(still its rye), wood, treacle, heat. Like rye.Earlier Rating: 2/10/2014 Total Score: 4.2Bottle shared by marcus at the California 10K event. Pours dark rusty brown with a slight tan head. Rye aroma - rich - suggesting barrel. Sweet and spicy aroma. Full bodied. Very sugary. Very rye spicey. Finishes that way. Extremely tasty. No heat whatsoever.

11/VII/14 - 75cl bottle as Rye Whiskey Bois @ Eerste "Er Klopt Iemand Op De Deur" Samson & Gert Bierproeving (aka Epic Beer Tasting III) - BB: n/a (2014-806) Thanks to PriorL and Mathieu87 for sharing the bottle!
Clear red brown beer, small irregular beige head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: chocolate, lots of alcohol, cocoa powder, dusty, sugary, caramel. MF: ok carbon, full body. Taste: sweet, sugary, vanilla, caramel, alcohol, little sour, some milk chocolate. Aftertaste: alcohol, sweet, vanilla, bit sour, caramel, sugary. Nice liquid dessert, love it!

750 ml "Bois" bottle shared with the Quebec City crew. Pours an orangeish brown with a short lived beige head. Aroma is booze, wood and caramel. Flavor is fruity caramel, brown sugar, wood and vanilla. Finish is vanilla, herbal, wood. Lingering...sugar! Strong body, velvety mouthfeel, weak carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2015 Rye Bois: I like the spiciness of the rye that beeks out above the booze and sweetness. Great sipper and an added level of complexity to an already complex, if sweet, beer.
Rye Sucre might be a 4.3, but Ill leave as is since I have to rate two beers as one.  How is Bois and Sucre different, but the BA are aliased.  :(

Bottle at first "Er klopt iemand op de deur" tasting aka EBT3. Thx to everyone for sharing todays beers!
APPEARANCE: clear brown beer, small unstable beige head.
NOSE: whiskey, alcohol, sweet.
TASTE: whiskey, little peated, alcohol.

Sampled as Bois Rye-Whiskey Barrel aged No head left, deep hazy brown beer. Chocolate, spirit, sweet, syrupy, and nutty aromas. Harsh-ish alcohol sweetness, chocolate and Belgian  pralines . Vanilla retronasal. Alcoholburn, wry, viscous-slick. Even more alcoholic than the others. Agressive, but in the end one keeps nipping from this one.

75 cl. bottle sampled @ "Er Klopt Iemand Op De Deur" Samson & Gert Bierproeving I. Thanks to Lisa! Tasted as The Bruery Bois (Rye Whiskey Barrel)  side by side: 5 version of Bois: Bourbon BA, Brandy BA, French Oak BA, New American Oak BA & Rye Whiskey BA. Pours hazy reddish brown with spare light brown head only on the sides, same look all five. Taste is similar to Bourbon BA, Brandy & New American Oak BA. Rye Whiskey adds a nice warmth and sweetness to the whole. This is my favourite after American Oak BA. Taste is same very sweet uniform mix of molasses, bread, toffee, bubble gum, toffee, brown sugar, nutmeg, vanilla, honey, clove, light barrel & warming character in the back. Thick, reach, chewy, soft carbonation, nice & rich stuff.

2013 Bois split 4 ways in a snifter. Pour is a fig colored murky red pour, light head. Nose has an explosion of rye spice and a lot of fig, grape skins and super caramelized oaky sweetness. The nose is really great....but you know what, the taste is EVEN BETTER! So caramelized, so sweet yet refined, lots of spicy caramel and honey and burnt brown sugar. like seriously this is awesome. my favorite after french oak and bourbon and brandy so 4th place for bois? not bad!

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2014 Bois bottle. Clear chestnut amber pour, with an off white head. Sweet and malty, rich caramel, whiskey, oak barrel, alcohol heat, sugars, raisin, vanilla, and fruitcake. Rich, syrupy sipping beer. Good.

Pours almost clear amber with a ring white head. Aroma is sweet and a bit boozy with bourbon, malts, whisky and quite some alcohol. Taste is quite sweet with some malts, alcohol, whisky and a medium bitterness. Medium body and carbo. Nice, but not really my type of beer.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2015 13 Mar 2015, tap at the Bruery. Tasted as Bois Rye edition (which redirects here). not a huge fan. this smells and tastes ridiculously sweet. almost like cola syrup, and almost as flat and syrupy. this is not good. 

(original rating 8 3 9 3 17 = 4.0) 1 June 2014, tap at the Bruery. Labeled rye barrel aged Bois. Brown. Nose is sweet, sugary alcohol, soft fruit, some nuts and fruitcake but not as bold as the standard Bois. Med/full body and mildly fizzy. Sugary, rich raisins, mild alcohol, no nutty bite. Really good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

May 25, 2014 - bottle from the source (Bois Rye). Brown pour with some head. Aroma was nice balance of alcohol, wood, spice caramel and malt. Taste was consistent with aroma and had a sweet and spicy finish. As it warmed, got some dark fruit in the taste. Medium to full body and smooth.
Backnote, had this beer at the zeebra extreem beer festival 2014. superb beer
Just as amazing as the normal Papier. Rich and diverse beer, pure brew art.
Pours a dark red orange unclear beer with a good tan head. Smells alcohol, bourbon. Tastes alcohol, rye and bourbon. Low carbo, medium body and a sticky texture.
Mooie oranje bruine bieren met een goede kraag. Ruikt vanille, crème, bourbon. Smaakt zoetig, vanille, crème en kruiden. Alcohol nasmaak.
Bottle. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Big rich sweet malts, light whiskey notes, caramel, and sweet fruits. Big and sweet and rich, but in a good way.

BOIS 750ml bottle pours a hazy brown with a thin tan head. Big boozy oak and caramel aroma. taste is the same with a bit of toffee sweet malt and dark fruit. For sure my favorite of the barrel aged series.

Bois Rye Whiskey Barrel - Pours dark brown with a ring of light tan head. Nose is sweet, with caramel, molasses, and a lot of heat. Taste is fruity booze, toffee, graininess--sweet and sugary. Slick and thick. Beers like this are just a mess of boozy and sweet flavors. I cant pick anything out and can usually barely finish my sample. Blech.
Bottle @ home  It pours dark brown with a medium light tan head loaded dark fruits, oak, bourbon, sweet, caramel, full body, toasted malt.

Draft at the brewery taproom. Pours clear amber with a light, creamy head. Tangy berries in the nose, some rich bread, toffee. Big sweet flavor, quite tasty, with further caramel, ripe fruits, cake. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Modest warmth to conclude with further fruit cake and toasted caramel. Decadent.
Bottle shared by marcus at california 10k event. Pours brown,black with not much head. Taste was big malts, dark fruits and oak
750 ml bottle at Cap Taps 10 K Celebration, very sweet, boozy in a good way.
Bottle from The Bruery. Pours orange brown with a modest beige head and a whiskey aroma. There is a sweet malt flavor with lots of vanilla and a sweeter finish. It all works quite well.

Pours a murky brown with a thin head. Served at room temp in a snifter the aroma is huge. Tons of sticky sweet toffee, rye whiskey barrel, caramel, vanilla, and a hint of an herbal bitterness. The barrel character is more pronounced than the regular Bois. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

pours dark brown-reddish with a small light beige head, some retention and spotty lacing, some legs too. chocolate and roasted malts, milk chocolate, burnt caramel, tobacco, leather, some dried ref fruits, hint of smoke, smooth vanilla and woodsy oakiness. moderate to low carbonation, medium body - oily, sticky, boozy and grassy-spicy finish. prefered over brandy-ba version. nice stuff to sip.

Bottle (750 ml). As "Bois Rye". From Marcus, thanks! Mahogany color with a small beige ring of foam. Aroma is of vanilla, caramel, booze, spices, brown sugar and sweetness notes. Taste is moderately sweet and boozy with caramel, brown sugar, spices, vanilla and a warming/burning finish. Full body. Low to moderate carbonation. Sirupy mouthfeel. Complex. Less fruity and better than the Brandy version. Quite complex. Too hot, but still an enjoyable sipper in small quantity.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours mahogany with very low beige head. Aroma is of alcohol, fruits, caramel, sugar. Taste is of malt, fruits, caramel, alcohol. Palate: Full bodied. Sticky texture. Overall: Good. Very hot warming alcohol. 100ml is kinda plenty. Boozy as hell.

Bottle shared by tom10101, thanks! Pours a reddish brown with no head and no lacing. Aroma is of raw alcohol and chocolate. Taste is sweet and boozy with a lot of dark brown sugar impressions. Boozy and sweet, just like the other The Bruery insanely strong ales. I liked this one better than the Brandy, dont ask me why though.

Dark orange color, moderate to large head, minimal lace/retention. Aroma is oak, caramel, wood, fruit. Full bodied, fairly well balanced for how powerful it is, somewhat vinous with a slight sherry like character. I thought the whiskey version would be rougher around the edges but it isnt.

Tap at The Bruery thanks to BMan1113VR! On tap as "Bois Rye Barrel Aged". Clear, super deep ruby pour with minimal wispy lines of tan foam. Nose is sticky, dark candies, sugar, soft rye barrel impending warmth. Taste is sticky, big twizzlers, dense dessert body. Right on the verge of cloying. Barrel spice could be upped higher. A massive dessert sipper.
Bottle at TSODRSG 13. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, oak, wood, rye. Flavour is malt, caramel, oak, wood, rye, alcohol, dried fruits, whiskey. Very nice beer.

(750ml bottle) cloudy medium brown, soapy creamy tan head. Nose of lightly spicy rye whiskey, rich date, caramel, graham cracker, rum soaked raisins. Taste of alcohol, caramel, dates, whiskey, raisins, lightly spicy especially in the finish. Creamy medium thick body.

Bois version (2013) with thanks to Felipe. Pours hazy chestnut with a small tan head and good lacing. Aroma is very sugary and malty, toffee, caramel, butterscotch, with just a bit of whiskey. Flavor is sweet with some rye present, light woody notes and astringence and little bitterness. As it warms up it becomes more comples with oak and vanilla notes. Medium body, a bit hot, but considering the ABV it is remarkably restrained. All in all a helluva beer.

2013 Bois aged in rye. Burnt caramel brown color, not much foam but it keeps a thin layer permanently. Almond, nutty, a little alcohol, wood. Similar flavor profile, a bit more peanut brittle for lack of a better phrase. Warm but very understated for 15 abv. Just good, hard to explain why it is so enjoyable. It just is.

Bottle at Matts with friends. Pour is murky brown with a small cream colored head and decent lacing. Coconut, whiskey, toffee, caramel, dark fruits, raisins, and figgy aroma. Taste is big raisins, figs, toffee, caramel, coconut, earthy, and roasty with a light alcoholic burn on the finish. Slick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Another good one.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, Bois version, dark brownish red pour with thin off white head, aroma brought notes of chocolate, dark fruit, lots of spice, hints of lots of oak, dark chocolate, lots of molasses, finishing bitter, sweet, slight earth.

Bottle @ Matts house from our Reserve Society membership. Pours a bit hazy reddish appearance with a thin tan head. Somewhat oxidized, caramel, spicy whiskey, apple, plum aroma. Pretty tasty, chocolate, caramel, slightly boozy, woody, vanilla flavor. I like this better than the Oak Bois but not as good as the bourbon version.

Bottle of Bois aged in Rye shared at Daves wedding. Aroma is liquid Heath bar. Chocolate, toffee, and a hint of molasses. Pours murky ugly brown with an ugly root beer float head. Taste is very nice with chocolate, toffee, tootsie roll, tobacco, and caramel. This was a great treatment. Still has an unsettling tobacco tartness up front but Im sure this will mellow.

750-ml bottle (2013 Bois). Pours a dark copper with a filmy head. Aroma of sweet, syrupy rye whiskey, toffee, heavy oak tones, and brown sugar. Perfect smooth blend of rye, caramel malt, cinnamon, brown sugar, with a dry oak finish on the taste. Slight heat, but not as much as the other spirit-aged versions. My favorite Bois; this needs no more aging, its ready now.

Trade from Sean9689, thanks buddy. Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering, 2013. Medium brown body with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is malt, hops, dark fruit like raisins, plums, dates, oak. Flavour is sweet, dark fruit, alcohol, oak, whiskey.

Bois - Rye Whiskey
A steady pour into my teku glass produces a two-finger thick, pale brown tinged, tan colored head. The beer is a concentrated brown / amber hue that shows deeply hazed, lighter version of the same when held up to the light. The aroma smells of sweet brown-whole-grain bread, rich caramelized malt notes, nutty, sherry like oxidation notes, and then some spicy, whiskey like notes towards the finish add some bite and balance to the up front richness and sweetness. Brown sugar syrup, vanillin notes, and caramelized toasted coconut aromas combine to make this seem like some sort of rich, decadent dessert. As the beer warms up hot alcohol, spicy wood notes, and whiskey like notes become a bit more noticeable.

Sweet, rich, satiating, and dense as it slides across the tongue. The carbonation is light in comparison to the rich body of this definite sipping beer. The alcohol is extremely well hidden for a beer of this strength, and it ends up being quite smooth despite the alcohol and the Whiskey barrel treatment. The sweetness is tempered by the richness, there is a nutty, slightly sherry like oxidation, as well as an almost smoky, salty, peat smoke like character that lingers just a bit in the finish. Ample notes of vanillin and toasted coconut are accentuated by the caramelized sweetness, and there is a touch of spicy woody character in the finish, all of which are barrel derived. 

Once again, I am quite a bit more impressed with this Bois variant than I was expecting. The alcohol is so well hidden for a beer of this strength, it is still warming and alcoholic, but it is well held in check and drinks like a beer far smaller than it is. You definitely have to be in the mood for a sweet, rich beer though; a small serving is definitely a good way to finish off the night.
Bois rye aged bottle. Dark reddish brown, off white head. Boozer rye whiskey and some nice beautiful tasty brew. The best of the bois variants. Damn Tasty!

Mahogany brown in color... Aroma of vanilla, oak, spices... Flavor is rye, vanilla, brown sugar toffee sweetness, alcohol and spice on the finish... Amazing... Bois rye whiskey

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

75cl, Vintage 2013, at 15%Vol, as Bois (100% Ale aged in Rye Whiskey Barrels), new exclusive American brew Anno 2013, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex brew, alcoholic/sweet and slightly vinous/woody, yet not too heavy, very balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew, yet very expensive!, WOW!
My Rating # 12600. Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering, 2013. Pours ruby amber with a small creamy head. Fruit, vanilla, rye, whiskey, dark fruit and alcohol. Smooth, soft and vinous. Full bodeid. Nice!

Bottle a "Bois Whiskey", Dark brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, toasted, oak and wood. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, cocunut, medium sweet, oak, rye, notes of alcohol, hop and medium bitter.

Sampled @ RB Danish Summer Gathering 2013 day 2, Ulfborg. Bottle. Clear dark red to autumn brownish color, medium sized beige to light brown head. Aroma is malts, wood, whiskey. Taste malts, lightly sweet, loads of whiskey, pretty alcoholic. Full body, medium carbonation. Heavy beer, a real sipper.

Bottle @ TSODRBSG13, Ulfborg. Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, chocolate, vanilla, dried fruit, wood and a little alcohol. Flavor is very sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish with lots of alcohol. 310813
Bottle @ Danish Ratebeer Summer Gathering. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are bourbon, vanilla, caramel, fruits, wood, malt and hops. Nice!

750, capped and waxed. Labelled as bois. Thanks j! Pours a cloudy dark brown with a dense and creamy tan head. Intensely sweet coconut, vanilla, and rye nose. Sticky thick body with soft carb. Caramel, vanilla, coconut, and some sweet peppery rye on the mid palate. Long sticky sweet finish. Kinda boozy.
Bois Version bomber. See notes under Bois. Add to it the always welcome spice of the rye whiskey barrels. Cuts through the sweetness just a tad. Kick ass as usual with these.

Bois version, shared by a friend. Clear reddish brown pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel and whiskey. Caramel and toffee flavor with a ton of whiskey before a spicy rye finish. In comparison with the bourbon version of Bois, sweeter overall, but also had the spicy rye finish the bourbon version didnt have.

Rye Bois, shared at a tasting. Pours a cloudy mahogany brown color wtih a small beige ring for a head. Big rye whiskey, especially on the aroma. Notes of vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, dates, figs, and oak. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, sticky mouthfeel. Liked this just a slight notch more than the New American Oak Bois.

Pours  thin dark brown with no head. The nose is vanilla, spice, citrus and caramel. Taste is high sweet no bitter. The body is heavy, creamy smooth and has a long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, Papier label with silver wax, 05/15/2013. Pours deep brown, maroon highlights, virtually no head aside from a few bubbles on the pour.  Aroma is nutty, woody rye whiskey notes with dark bready malts, light fruitiness with caramel cola, vanilla and oak. Taste is fruity, chocolate caramel toffee, some  bitterness blending with a little heat, spicy whiskey finish. Not at all as sweet as the Brandy tried yesterday. Full body, thicker than the Brandy as well, which makes this more enjoyable, smooth for the ABV. Well done, very enjoyable.
Tasted in 2009 (backlog). Brown with almost no head. Aroma is rye, malt, whiskey, caramel, brown sugar, maple, and molasses. Taste is of booze, molasses, and bown sugar.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2013 Big thanks to Mike for opening the trifecta! Rye was the least barrel-forward of the three, allowing the base its due time in the spotlight. Caramely sweetness throughout, aged booze warms my throat. Quite different from the other two, and really tasty in its own right. My favorite of the three.

17th September 2011Cloudy dark brown beer. Woody rye nose with a little vanilla. Smooth palate, zero carbonation. Nice mild sour rye well integrated with a little vanilla wood. Nice dark chocolate and a trace of dark fruits. Semi dry finish. Surprisingly little heat. Nice.

Bottle Ive been hoarding since June 2009. Opened for my dads 50thparty bday party. Murky muddy brown pour with not very much head. This beer has definitely mellowed out with age. Tastes of molasses, toffee, chocolate fruit and spiced whiskey. Low carbonation. Great brew for sure.
Tried this beer at the Casanova Beer Cave Festival (2011), nice dark brown with a pleasant roast taste.

Blind tasting at YesprBrown color; no head. The aroma shows sweet malt and caramel, with a gentle wood. Good body strength; the malt and caramel flavor are well sweet, but the mouthfeel doesnt get syrupy also because of the strong alcohol presence. Strong bitterness, with limited nutty presence. The final is more burning and nutty. This one as well is a bit too alcoholic for being really appreciated.
(750ml bottle).  Pours brown with alcohol aroma.  Full bodied with alcohol burn.  Very appreciative of the taste.

A: The pour is a muddy and hazy amber color with no carbonation and a few bubbles after the initial pour.

S: Lots of whiskey right off the bat with vanilla, oak, tobacco and leather being quite evident as well. The base beer provides a great sweetness to the nose with caramel, toffee, and molasses.

T: Really great rye whiskey flavor up front with oak and vanilla following closely behind. Caramel, molasses, and toffee provide a great sweetness too.

M: The body is quite full with essentially no carbonation or bubbles at all.

D: Like with all the Bruery Anniversary ales, very easy to drink despite the monster ABV. This one goes down super smooth.

Hazy mahogany with a tiny beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and bourbon notes. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel, dark overripe fruits, bourbon, vanilla, drying hops and oak. Finished sweet.

Bottled. Tasted blind. An unclear red beer with a thin orangey head. The aroma has notes of alcohol, caramel sauce, and some liquor. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, alcohol, wood, berries, and liquor, leading to a dry, alcoholic, and woody finish.

Hazy amber colour, small head. Aroma is dark dry fruits, plum, alcohol, mild spices, fudge and alcohol. Flavour is alcohol, dark fruits, nectar and quite much toffee, dark dry fruits and some mild sugary notes as well.

Bottle 75 cl. Blindtasting. Pours a cloudy opaque dark brown with a small, rough brownish head. Sweet aroma of wood and Port. Full-bodied, low carbonation, wood, overripe fruit, Port notes and a rather alcoholic finish. 060510

Bottle. Good vinous aroma, quite sweet, some vanilla. 
Cloudy dark brown colour. No head. The flavour is sweet and vinous. Good vanilla note. Dried fruit. Roasted barley finish. Quite alcoholic. The sweetness almost balances it, though.

Bottled. Tasted as blind # 5 @ yesprs. Reddish brown coloured. Light brown fluffy head. Aroma of prunes, sweetnes, spice, wood and sherry. Flavour of light wood, alcohol, sweetness, rye, ripe fruits and again light sherry. Medium to full bodied. Heavy alcohol bite on palate and lips in the end.

Bottle 750ml. @ yesprs Pre tasting before the Copenhagen beerfestival. [ Blindtasting Bottle #5. ]Unclear medium brown amber color with a small, fizzy and open, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, dark berry, wood - oak, vanilla, light alcohol, port - whisky. Flavor is light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, dark berry, hot alcohol, sweet tart berry notes. Body is medium to full, texture is oily - syrupy, carbonation is flat, finish feel is moderate alcoholic. [20100506]

Bottle # 5 at yesprs blindtasting.
Hazy red brown coloured with a small off-white head.
Sweet aroma of caramel, liquorice, chocolate, bourbon, oak and vanilla.
Sweet and fruity flavour of liquorice, chocolate, port wine, oak and vanilla with notes of alcohol.
Warming alcoholic finish.

75 cL bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted dark malt, distinct whiskey note. Sweet and sugarish dark toffee malty flavoured. Vague breadish note. Sweet and hot alcohol too. Sweet and malty into a warming finish.

Bottle #427 provided to me by WeeHeavySD, Go raibh maith agat Jon! Shared with Shawn and friends.  Deep brown hue with a ruby highlight, minimal head and no lace. Oily tears upon the glassware. The aroma has notes of marizpan, rye whiskey, fig, raisin, pale grains and roast, chocolate and vanilla, clove and pepper, and a touch of smoke. Wonderful nose! The taste has a big malty presence with dark fruit and spicy undertones. The malt character screams Old English Strong Ale and there is a maintaining earthy and tobacco tone from start to finish, Moderate alcohol found upon the finish. The mouth feel is shockingly aggressive and sharp, oily and full-bodied to counteract the booze. OUT FRICKEN STANDING, Big, Bold but yet refined. I really need to try to get the other versions of the Papier, and you should too!

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 Bottle shared by Mike BBB63.  Notes of Aroma of brown sugar, syrup,  whiskey.  Reminded me of a mix between tenancious cassis and fourth demensia.    super Sweet, doughy.  tough to drink.  Some booze, caramel, warming.  Not overly complex, big and sweet and warming. a bit too sticky sweet, syrupy, and one dimensional for how big it is.

Bottle at Reserve Society Initiation party. Tried all four different versions available. This was my least favorite. This was similar to the other, but the least integrated, harshest and least complex. Not bad, but the regular version is much better.

From a bottle at the Bruerys 1st anniversary party 5/16/09: Pours a viscous transparent dark copper mahogany with a thin ring of off-white head.  Aroma of fresh whiskey oak and complex raisins and brown sugar.  Starts with good fullness and sweet toasty dark caramel with a hint of chocolate and plums.  Finishes warming and semi-sweet with some butterscotch.  A nicely balanced and enjoyable brew that should continue to age well.

bottle thanks to bman1113vr.  The look is cloudy, brown in color, not much head, but some legs.  The smell is wood, lots of alcohol, malts, sweet, and good.  The taste is sweet, malts, whiskey, wood, and alcohol.

Bottle poured into glass at The Bruery Reserve Society Initiation.  This is review #1450 for me.  Yes, I do realize that is hardly a milestone and nobody cares.  Deal with it.  Thanks to our massive beer-pooling efforts and relentless attacks on the tasting table, we were able to amass quite a bit of each -bal aged Papier incarnation.  This was the best of the Papiers, with a heavenly flavor that is likely to result in a beergasm when you first try it.  Pours a muddy brown color with minimal head.  Its not very pretty appearance-wise, but the true beauty lies within, sort of like the girl Jack Blacks character dated in "Shallow Hal."  It is in fact one of lifes great ironies that this beer is the same color as crap, but its aroma and flavor are the exact opposite.  Not that I have ever tasted crap.  Aroma is amazing, with smooth rye whiskey, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, dark fruits, vanilla, and oak. Flavor has all these same notes, coming together incredibly well, with a strong but not overwhelming rye whiskey presence.  Smooth and almost creamy on the palate, with medium-full body, not too boozy but having great alcohol warmth. Carbonation is low but not nonexistent.  If you are going to pony up something super-rare to trade for a -bal aged Papier, try to make it this one.  It is absolutely LEGEN...wait for it, and I hope youre not lactose intolerant because here comes the...dary.

Rating number 2900. Silver waxed bottle from the Bruery that I shared with a few amazing members from Ratebeer. Pours with no head and a hazy, deep brown body. Aroma of maple syrup, sugar, oak, brown sugar, booze and some dry spicy whiskey notes. Awesome! Taste is brown sugar, port, caramelized raisins, and oak. Not super drinkable with the ABV, I must say, but surely a nice sipper. Syrupy and boozy, which is my sort of thing. A great beer!

bottle thanks to bman1113vr.  poured maroonish with some nice legs left of the glass when swirled.  aroma was caramel, dark fruits, and oak.  flavor was caramel, oak, dark fruits, and alcohol.  light body with a nice slick feeling.  one of my favorites on the day.
bottle thanks to bman1113vr.  cloudy brown with no head.  wood, vanilla, rye and light alcohol on teh nose.  very smooth on the palate, great flavors of rye, malts and a smooth vanilla wood finish.

Bottle from Bman311vr, nice to finally crack into one of these three.  Pours brownish cloudy orange with a nice white head.  Nose is sweet, and wildily complex.  Taste is boozy but very very tasty, I likey.
Bottle courtesy of BMan1113VR. Dark maroon pour. Sweet alcohol scents with bready notes. Sweet for sure. Taste is hardcore heavy malt. Sweet flavors with lots of alcohol on the upfront. Solid.
Bottle thanks to bman1113vr. Aroma is bourbon, caramel, vanilla, wood. Flavor is vanilla, bourbon, caramel, and boozy.

When I rate this I see an average score of 4.15, with a ratebeer score of 3.54.  Thats OK with me, but when I look at Bruerys beer listing and sort by rating, this comes out very low, even though it may become one of their highest rated beers.  I wish the listing would display the average score on the Bruery page, but still use the ratebeer score for ranking purposes.  This way I can look at the Bruery page and tell at a glance what is good.  From bottle at BA Papier release at the Bruery.  Wow.  Smells really great. Sweet.  Delicious.  Very boozy, but suprizingly easy to drink. Buttery vanilla barrel aged aroma.

Dr. Bill Tasting - Falling Rock - GABF 2009: A reddish/amber colored beer with pretty much no head to speak of.  The nose is boozy, sweet, and full of molassis.  The flavors are again boozy...and sweet, yet tangy..and pretty damn BIG.  a little less refined than the other papiers, but still a nice sipper.

( 750ml bottle )  Pours a cloudy brown body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of bourbon, raisins, toffee, and vanilla.  Flavor of  bourbon, vanilla, brown sugar, dates, raisins, and toffee with a dry wood finish.  Excellent!

Bottle.  Glad as hell I got to try one of these BA papiers!! Dark brown pour with a small head.  Tons of sweetness in the nose.  Maply syrup, cane syrup, dark agave nectar, brown sugar, booze, and maybe even a roasted marshmallow.  Flavor is sweet and lingers forever.  Vanilla, booze, brown sugar, syrup, and dark fruit.  Yeah its damn good.
Pours dark and murky brown with no head. Nose and flavor are whiskey, maple, brown sugar and some alcohol. Smooth on the palate.

Bottle. Brown with little to no head. Just the right amouint of carbonation for the style. Smooth and silky mouthfeel. Tastes of vanilla, dried dates, maple syrup and wood. Complex and well balanced. Best of the three.

Bottles at The Bruerys anniversary.   Dark brown with a small head.   Mellow whiskey, lots of wood, and smoke in the aroma.   The flavor is a silky blend of smooth whiskey, vanilla, malt, brown sugar and wood.   Full bodied and silky.   The best of the three bottled versions.
Bottle pour at the Bruerys 1st Anniv, nicely balanced, good complexity, very tasty. best of the three
1st rating. This was the best of the three versions. Very well balanced, with that smooth rye flavor, very well done, Im looking fotward to getting a bottle of this.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA
